info.description: Myanmar Rohingya refugee woman hold her son seen after arriving on a boat to Bangladesh on Shah Porir Dip Island at Cox’s Bazar 14 September 2017.

Rohingya Muslims, trying to cross the Naf River into Bangladesh to escape sectarian violence in Myanmar, look on from an intercepted boat in Teknaf on 11 June 2012. Bangladesh was refused three more boatloads of Rohingya Muslims fleeing sectarian violence in Myanmar, officials said, despite growing calls for the border to be opened. Bangladeshi guards have turned back 16 boats carrying more than 660 Rohingya people, most of them women and children, since June 11 as they tried to enter from neighboring Myanmar across the river Naf.

Rohingya Muslims, trying to cross the Naf River into Bangladesh to escape sectarian violence in Myanmar, look on from an intercepted boat in Teknaf on 11 June 2012. Bangladesh was refused three more boatloads of Rohingya Muslims fleeing sectarian violence in Myanmar, officials said, despite growing calls for the border to be opened. Bangladeshi guards have turned back 16 boats carrying more than 660 Rohingya people, most of them women and children, since June 11 as they tried to enter from neighboring Myanmar across the river Naf.

Bangladeshi guards have turned back 16 boats carrying more than 660 Rohingya people, most of them women and children, since June 11 as they tried to enter from neighboring Myanmar across the river Naf.

3 days in River no food, no shelter people are staying in boat with rain. Rohingya Muslims, trying to cross the Naf River into Bangladesh to escape sectarian violence in Myanmar, look on from an intercepted boat in Teknaf on 13 June 2012.

Smoke billows above what is believed to be a burning village in Myanmar's Rakhine state as members of the Rohingya Muslim minority take shelter in a no man's land between Bangladesh and Myanmar in Ukhia on 04 September 2017.
Thousand of Rohingya refugees people crossing the Bangladesh and Myanmar border area to take shelter in Bangladesh as they fled from Myanmar Rakahain on 09 October 2017.
Thousand of Rohingya refugees people crossing the Bangladesh and Myanmar border area to take shelter in Bangladesh as they fled from Myanmar Rakahain on 02 November 2017.

A bullet was found in the Ulubunia Bazar area close to the Bangladesh-Myanmar border on 06 September 2017. Villagers say that after a gunfight this bullet comes from the Myanmar side and falls in their place in Bangladesh.

Sona Banu gets carried by Nobi Hossain to the shore of the Naf River as they fled from Myanmar on 27 September 2017. Hundreds of Rohingya arrive by boats in the safety of darkness on Shah Porir Dwip island in Teknaf, Bangladesh
X-ray report of Sanoura Begum who was shot by the Myanmar army when she escaped from Myanmar Rakhine state, now she is under treatment at Cox’s Baar Sadar Hospital Bangladesh, 07 October 2017.

The body of 6-month-old Jamal Hossain was washed before his burial in an unregistered Leda refugee camp in Teknaf, Bangladesh on 26 November 2016. On November 26 in the dark Nur Begam reached Bangladesh refugee camp with her child's skinny body while she was fleeing from Myanmar where stateless people are under attack. But after getting everything like food, shelter, and a doctor the little boy Jamal Hossain can't survive. He lost his life early morning on the same day.

Asmat Ara feels traumatized during the recent violence in Myanmar on 06 September 2017, in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. She entered last night Tenkhali Rohingya refugee camp from kumir khali Myanmar Rohingya state with her family member.
A Rohingya refugee father carried his son in a basket walked through a paddy field and entered Bangladesh from Myanmar Rakhine state at Anjumanpara in Coxsbazar, Bangladesh on 02 November 2017
Hundreds of Rohingya people crossed Bangladesh's and Myanmar's border to take shelter in Bangladesh as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar on 09 September 2017.
A Rohingya refugee woman with her child walks through a muddy field way to Teknaf refugee shelter in Bangladesh on 28 September 2017
After eight days of hard walking from Myanmar Rakhine state an old Rohingya man takes a rest just after entering Bangladesh on 09 September 2017

The body of a Rohingya refugee is brought to shore after being recovered from the Naf River, as scores of refugees tried to flee from Myanmar to Bangladesh, near Ulubunia in Ukhiya on September 6, 2017. The victim was shot by Myanmar soldiers when he was crossing the Naf River, according to the refugees who recovered the bodies from the river
A Rohingya refugee family walks through a paddy field in the border area to take shelter in Bangladesh as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar on 05 September 2017
A Myanmar helicopter was seen in the Bangladesh and Myanmar border area where Myanmar Rohingya people waiting to enter Bangladesh in Palongkhali, Cox's Bazar on 02 November 2017.
According to the UNHCR, more than 9,43,000 Rohingya refugees have fled from Myanmar since 25 August 2017 to take shelter in Bangladesh.
A Rohingya refugee family stuck in the rain entered Shaw Pori island way to Teknaf in Bangladesh on 09 September 2017.
Hundreds of Rohingya people crossed the Bangladesh border as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar to take shelter in Bangladesh on 09 October 2017.
A Rohingya family crosses a canal between Bangladesh and Myanmar border area as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar om 9 October 2017
A Rohingya Muslim family crosses a fence as they enter Bangladesh from Myanmar Rakhine state near the Bangladesh-Myanmar border in Teknaf, Bangladesh, 04 September 2017.

After eight days of hard walking from Myanmar Rakhine state an old Rohingya man takes a rest just after entering Bangladesh on 09 September 2017

The body of a Rohingya refugee is brought to shore after being recovered from the Naf River, as scores of refugees tried to flee from Myanmar to Bangladesh, near Ulubunia in Ukhiya on September 6, 2017. The victim was shot by Myanmar soldiers when he was crossing the Naf River, according to the refugees who recovered the bodies from the river
A Rohingya refugee family walks through a paddy field in the border area to take shelter in Bangladesh as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar on 05 September 2017
A Myanmar helicopter was seen in the Bangladesh and Myanmar border area where Myanmar Rohingya people waiting to enter Bangladesh in Palongkhali, Cox's Bazar on 02 November 2017.
According to the UNHCR, more than 9,43,000 Rohingya refugees have fled from Myanmar since 25 August 2017 to take shelter in Bangladesh.
A Rohingya refugee family stuck in the rain entered Shaw Pori island way to Teknaf in Bangladesh on 09 September 2017.
Hundreds of Rohingya people crossed the Bangladesh border as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar to take shelter in Bangladesh on 09 October 2017.
A Rohingya family crosses a canal between Bangladesh and Myanmar border area as they fled from Buchidong in Myanmar om 9 October 2017
A Rohingya Muslim family crosses a fence as they enter Bangladesh from Myanmar Rakhine state near the Bangladesh-Myanmar border in Teknaf, Bangladesh, 04 September 2017.
Mojid Bangladeshi young youth poses for pictures when he was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on August 13, 2020. He say’s “after unloading 32 basket coal I got around $1”.

Ripon a Bangladeshi young youth poses for pictures when he was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on August 13, 2020. He has come to Dhaka city from a remote village Panchagor. He was trying to study. But his family condition is no good. To support his family, he did not get the chance to go to school.

Antor Hossain a Bangladeshi young youth poses for pictures when he was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on August 13, 2020. He is a student and living in the village of Manikgonj. His father and mother are doing day labor jobs in Dhaka city. Before the Covid-19 lockdown, he came to saw his family. But after lockdown, all the school closes. That’s why he thinks to work this coalfield to earns money for his family.

Al Kadnur a Bangladeshi young youth poses for pictures when he was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on September 14, 2020. One year ago, he moves to Dhaka from a village Bramonbaria. He told, “his family doing farming”. But day by day villagers losing the farming environment for various reason like climate change, Industrial pollutions. That’s why he moves to Dhaka to support his family and start doing the labour job. Because this job easy to get in the capital city of Dhaka

Rita a Bangladeshi young girl poses for pictures when she was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on September 14, 2020. After losing her house by the river erosion she moves to Dhaka with 5 family members around 10 years ago from village Vola. After entering Dhaka city first her mother starts working as labour. That time Rita tries to do educations. But a few years later observing her mother she starts doing the same labour job to run their family.

Rahela (55) poses for pictures when she was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on August 13, 2020. Before the Covid-19 pandemic in Bangladesh, she works door to door in the Dhaka city as a maid. When the Covid-19 pandemic starts people don’t allow to enter any outsider in their home. And Rahela lost her daily job. Without founding any option, she starts working as day labour in coal unloading ship.

Chandrababu (50) poses for pictures when she was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on September 14, 2020. After losing her all the homeland by the river erosion she moves to Dhaka with 4 family members around 15 years ago from village Sherpur. She says 'I don't have any educations that's why I can do only labour job'.

Khala (65) poses for pictures when she was working on a coal unloading ship in Dhaka, Bangladesh on September 14, 2020. With her family around thirty years ago, she moves to Dhaka from a village chapainawabganj. After entered the Dhaka city, Khala was doing various kind of job to feed her children. Now her all the children got married and left him. Now she is alone. That’s why Khala still working as day labour to survive.
